results.title: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.brief_description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for Dream A Little Crazy (2013) is no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy.

constellations_primary.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_primary.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

results.title_for_label: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.
description_for_label: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Somebody that I used to know
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.

constellations_primary.name: Viral music videos
constellations_primary.description: Gotye's 'Somebody that I used to know' was one of the internet's most viral music videos, seconded only to Queen Bey's 'Singles Ladies'.

results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.

results.title: Technology/transformation: Wonder Woman
results.brief_description: ‘Technology/Transformation: Wonder Woman’ is an incendiary deconstruction of the ideology embedded in television and pop cultural iconography. Through radical manipulation of the female pop icon, Wonder Woman, Birnbaum subverts and reshapes its meaning within the television text.
results.description: ‘Technology/Transformation: Wonder Woman’ is an incendiary deconstruction of the ideology embedded in television and pop cultural iconography. Through radical manipulation of the female pop icon, Wonder Woman, Birnbaum subverts and reshapes its meaning within the television text.

results.title: Contests USA
results.brief_description: Skip Blumberg presents, in his customary fashion, a series of short films examining the bizarre and the sublime in America in the 1980s. ‘Summer Ski Jumping’ follows the 33rd annual event ski enthusiasts who take over the Olympic ski jump in Lake Placid on the 4th of July and execute jumps over imported snow sometimes during temperatures reaching 100 degrees. ‘Ugly Dog Contest’ presents a subversion of the traditional dog show with a series of unusual looking dogs in line to take the prize of ugliest dog. ‘Festival of the Saw’ captures the international celebration of saw playing in Santa Cruz, with an examination of the demise of saw playing during the 1920s and its subsequent revival.

results.title: New dance
results.brief_description: Several short pieces in which individuals or groups of dancers work with the idea of ‘minimal choreography’, using simple props such as balls, rods and firesticks to create complicated patterns and rhythms from a few basic movements. The result is a quirky hybrid of circus skills and dance, augmented by some image manipulation in the edit suite.

results.title: JGLING/Whistling
results.brief_description:
JGLING:
Close up low-angle shots of a juggler in action bring the viewer right inside the circle of flying objects.

This short video captures the almost hypnotic appeal of watching a skilled juggler at work; the visual rhythms, the ever changing patterns, and the pleasurable anticipation of collapse.

THE FIRST INTERNATIONAL WHISTLING CONTEST:
The First International Whistling Contest was held in Carson, Nevada, 1978. This documentary captures the sweet sounds and light-hearted atmosphere of the day. The participating whistlers not only perform a range of tunes in a variety of styles, from the classical to the comic, but also share details of their technique.
From the man who whistles with a bunch of cigars and cutlery in his mouth, to the woman who claims she could have had a career at Disney animation because, “You can’t hardly get a bird to whistle when you want to”, these characters and their talents are showcased in a style that is immediate, fresh and breezy.

Director Skip Blumberg was a founding member of Videofreex, one of the many alternative media collectives (such as Raindance, Global Village, Ant Farm and TVTV) that blossomed in the 1970s in response to the development of relatively cheap and portable video systems such as Sony’s Portapak. This new technology was embraced both by artists interested in its aesthetic properties and activists inspired by its potential as a tool of political and social change, enabling individuals access to mass communication via cable television and community media networks.

results.title: Corps flottant
results.brief_description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. Men bathe in the thermal springs of Kusatu, while an elderly woman tends to a rice paddy. Cahen creates a dream-like chronicle of the landscape and develops a painterly impression of the figures who exist within that landscape.
results.description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. results.title: Meet the People
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Blurring the line between documentary and fiction, truth and artifice, Meet the People presents fourteen ‘characters’ who face the camera in talking head close-ups and speak about their lives and dreams. The intimacy and honesty of their fragmented, autobiographical storytelling is illusory; the credits reveal that these people are professional actors, playing fictional roles, reading a script. As Silver writes, this work points to a complicity on the part of the viewer in his desire to believe and identify with the traditions of and characters on TV. The same television that mimics a perfected form of the identity of the ‘average person’ is also in part responsible for creating this identity; it both researches, uses and manufactures this ‘average person’s‘ hopes and dreams. And so the question of a ‘real person’ becomes ‘real’ compared to what?

results.title: Tony Oursler: Selected works
results.brief_description: These early examples of Oursler’s ingenious video theater are bizarre tales of good and evil. Crudely executed, they are as funny as they are chilling. Life is a series of spontaneous, dryly humorous episodes about the absurdity and grotesqueness of everyday life. Oursler writes: “When I look around I see that life is pregnant with pleasures and dangers. I get confused. We come down the chute and start out O.K. Then everything is go go go until you… you know what happens.” Diamond (Head) is a tale of lust and greed, starring a triangular-shaped cardboard protagonist who marries and has a “Good Son” — a small, foetus-shaped balloon. Good Things and Bad Things, which introduces Oursler’s recurring theme of the interdependence of good and evil, culminates in a wild vignette in which the artist plays the role of a young woman in a violent world turned sideways.

results.title: Olympic fragments
results.brief_description: Commissioned for the 1980 Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid, New York, Olympic Fragments is a taut, expressive reinterpretation of athletic movement, a tour-de-force of dynamic editing and post-production techniques. Through sophisticated visual and aural juxtapositions, Fitzgerald and Sanborn isolate the gestures and movements of athletes in a controlled, powerful display. Eschewing the ‘thrill of victory’ tradition of broadcast television sports coverage, they allow a portrait of individual skill and grace under pressure to emerge from their manipulation of highly fragmented and choreographed imagery — what they term the ‘skill, beauty and sheer joy of kineticism.’
